div.head: Insurances
div.p: THE undersigned having been appointed agents in China for the above COMPANY, are prepared to accept ASSURANCE at Shanghae. as under

1st. On Buildings of Brick or Stone, covered with Tiles, Slates, Metal, or other Incombustible Material, when such Buildings are isolated from all others, Rate of Premium, 3/4 per cent per Annum. And on their Contents, at the Rate of 1 per cent
Assurances for 6 Months 3/4, and for 3 Months 1/2, of the Annual Rate will be charged.
ASSURANCES, for the present, will be accepted to the extent of £7,000 only on one Risk.
A Building and its Contents taken together form one Risk. Thus the above Sum may be underwritten either on a Building alone, or the Contents alone ; or, part on the Building, and part on the
No ASSURANCE is to be considered in force until the Premium be paid.
Amongst other advantages of the COMPANY, the ASSURED will be entitled to participated in the Profits after Five successive payments.
Parties applying for ASSURANCES will please send in full particulars of the Risk to be taken; any Deviation from which without the Consent of the COMPANY, will vitiate the POLICY.
JARDINE, MATHESON & Co., Agents in Shanghae.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: IS hereby given that the Partnership heretofore subsisting between us. the undersigned as General and Commission. Merchants at Shanhae in China, under the firm of THOS. RIPLEY & Co, has this day terminated by effluxion of time, and is accordingly dissolved.
Dated this Thirty-first day of December, One thousand Eight hundred and Fifty.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE Firm of THOS. RIPLEY & Co., having terminated yesterday, I have taken into Partnership Mr. JOSEPH BLAND, (Nephew of Mr. Thos. Ripley), to continue the business as General and Commission Merchants from this date under the firm of SHAW, BLAND & Co.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE BUSINESS, as Merchant & Agent, heretofore conducted in this place, by Mr. FAZULBHOY. GOOLAMHOOSUN, in his own name, will from this date be continued by him under the designation of our firm

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE undersigned have formed a PARTNERSHIP, for the practice of MEDICINE and SURGERY, from this date.
GEORGE ROGERS HALL, A.B.; M.D. JOHN IVOR MURRAY, M.D.; M.R.C.S.E. Shanghae, 1st October, 1850.

div.head: Miscellaneous

No. 3, of 17 th ultimo, will be reprinted very shortly, in the form of a Pamphlet, price 10 cents each copy.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: THE Community is respectfully informed, that all Communications, Advertisements, and insertions for the following number, should be sent, on or before Thursday in each week, or they will be too late for the same week's issue.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: JOB PRINTING in all its branches, will be executed at our office, on the usual terms, with the greatest attention and despatch.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: LOCAL BUSINESS.—The Bank receives Money in Deposit as follows:—
1. For 3 Months certain, hearing Interest at
3. For 6 Months certain, bearing Interest at 4 per cent per annum.
4. For 1 Year certain, repayable on 3 Months notice, at 6 per cent per annum.
4. In Current Account, withdrawable on demand in Sums of 10 dollars and upwards.
Current Accounts are kept in Spanish Dollars, balanced Half Yearly, bear no Interest, and are subject to the following Commissions, vis :— When the amount turned over during the
Half Year is under 2,000 dollars, a Half-yearly Charge of 5 dollars will he made.
Do. do. do. 25,000 dollars, 1/4 per cent on the amount
The rate of Commission when the amount turned over exceeds 25,000 dollars, will be fixed by special agreement
Inoperative Accounts will be subject to an Annual Charge on the balance at the above rates.
The Bank issues Notes payable on demand, and grants Bank Post Bills at Three Days' sight free of charge.
The Bank grants Loans and Cash Accounts upon various approved Securities, and discounts approved Bills and Promissory Notes not having a longer period than 3 months to run.

EXCHANGE.—The Bank receives Tenders for the purchase of Bills on England and India, and sells its own Drafts on the Union Bank of London at One Day's to Six Months’ sight and on the National Bank of Scotland and Provincial Bank of Ireland at Short sight; also on the Three Presidences of India, and on Ceylon and Singapore, at Three Days’ to Sixty Days’ sight
Information more in detail will be given at the Bank's Offices here, in Canton, and Shanghae.

div.head: PRESENT PRICES OF PROVISIONS SUPPLIED AT THE SHANGHAE MARKET.

div.p: We have just received the Anglo Chinese Calendar for 1851,* it contains as usual a great variety of useful information.
We select the few following Chinese Proverbs:
“ Not to distinguish properly between the beautiful and ugly, is like attaching a dog’s tail to a squirrel's body.
An avaricious man, who can never have enough, is as a serpent wishing to swallow an elephant.
While one misfortune is going to have another coming, is like driving a tiger out of the front door, while a wolf is entering the back.
To ride a fierce dog to catch a lame rabbit (Useless power over a contemptible enemy.
To attack a thousand tigers with ten men; to attempt a difficulty with incommensurate means.)
To cut off a hen’s head with a battle-axe; (unnecessary valor.)
To instigate a villain to do wrong, is like teaching a monkey to climb trees.
A pigeon sneering at a rock;—a mean man despising a prince.
The fish sports in the kettle, but his life will not be long.
Like a sheep dressed in a tiger’s skin is a superficial scholar.
Like a cuckoo in a magpie’s nest, is one who enjoys another’s labor.
Do not pull up your stockings in a melon field, or arrange your hat under a peach tree, lest people think you are stealing.
By a long journey we know a horse’s strength; so length of days shows a man’s heart”
*To be had at Messrs. H. Fogg & Co.’s

div.head: Atmospherical Changes, During the Week ending 9th January, 1851.
div.p: The first part of the last seven days continued fine weather; Monday and Tuesday being damp and disagreeable, followed on Wednesday and to-day by hard frost. The average temperature of the week has been very nearly that of the corresponding week of last year: in 1850 the mercury standing at 38.6°, and during the past week at 39.2°.

DEATH.—In Shanghae; on Saturday, the 3rd instant, at the house of Messrs. Wolcott, Bates & Co., Captain C. H. Cooksey, of the American Barque Huntingden.
DEATH.—10th inst, W. F. Robinson, Esq., of Salem Mass., U. S. A., aged 35 years. —

div.head: John Dugdale
div.p: The topic of the week in our little community, has been the detention of the John Dugdale, on the ground of some part of the Tea cargo not having paid the legal duty. We arc happy to have in our power to lay before our readers the detail of this occurrence and the correctness of which we think cannot he contested, our information being derived from parties wholly cognisant of the circumstances and whose characters will guarantee full credence to the statement. The cargo of the John Dugdale, consists wholly of Tea shipped by four parties, the duty receipts preparatory to clearing the vessel were forwarded to her consignees on Saturday last, and on reference thereto they found, that the vessel was about to clear with a cargo of about half the quantity she had taken on her previous voyage. It should he mentioned that no part of the cargo was shipped by the Consignees of the vessel. The Port Clearance had been granted and forwarded to the Consul when the Consignees of the vessel arrived at the Consulate and laid an information against the several shippers by this vessel alleging that they had one and all smuggled the greater part of the cargo and demanded the Consul’s interference in order to visit upon the offenders the full penalties of their wrong doing—the Consignee, moreover, lodged a formal protest against any damages oc-curing to the ship in consequence of the legal duties not having been paid, and late in the same evening, the several shippers were served with a notice that they were held responsible for any losses arising from detention of the ship, by any irregularity in payment of duties. No other course consistent with his official duty could be pursued by Her Majesty's Consul than that adopted by him on this occasion ; he immediately communicated with the Taoutai and returned the grand chop, and as the vessel had been permitted in the meantime to drop down below the anchorage, a messenger was sent to seal the hatches and she was ordered back off the Chinese Custom-house.

On reference to the manifest as given by the Consignees to the Consul, it was found (after the grand chop had been issued) that there was a deficiency of 2,000 chests on which no duty whatever had been paid ; no intimation of this discrepancy had been hinted at or pointed out by the Consignee to the party interested, who on ascertaining the omission applied on the

earliest occasion to the Custom-house and tendered "the duty"; it was refused on the plea that the accounts of the John Dug-dale had been closed, and the vessel "had cleared. In the meantime the Consul had been in communication with the Taoutai and it had been intimated to the parties concerned, that the whole cargo would-be landed and re-weighed and such portion -thereof on which it should appear that the duty had been evaded, should be confiscated by the Chinese authorities.Subsequent-ly,—thanks to the judicious intervention of the Consul, it was determined not to discharge the cargo, and it was deemed by him, that this was not a case which merited the infliction of the penalties arising under the Imperial treaty, seeing that the laxity or corrupt connivance of the Customs-house officers has led to such a state, that non-payment of the full duty upon Teas has now become the custom of the port ; so much so, that even in this case of the John Dugdale (with the deficiency of
2,000 chests on which no duty whatever was paid and others in which one sixth and on third only was paid), still paid in respect of her tonnage, more export
duty than 3/4ths of the vessels recently

We feel certain that our readers will heartily approve of the Consular decision in this case, which was, that the shippers should declare the respective quantities shipped and be amerced by the infliction of double duties on the quantity not previously paid, and a further fine for their irregularity, of 100 dollars each, to the Queen.

We sincerely hope that this Consular decision will be accepted as a warning for the future, and we think we know enough of the right-mindedness and correct feeling of our readers to say that the great lenity accorded in this instance to the offending parties, will not be construed into the belief that the Chinese authorities will be as apathetic and indifferent as they have been of late, to the daily (we might say hourly) systematic evasions, of the legal duties both in imports and exports,—sorry should we be, that such a state of things, should permanently obtain in this recent but rising port as has disgraced Canton from time immemorial. We are assured by the best informed of our friends that it is not only inexpedient, but absolutely expensive in its results to the shipper ; as it has been satisfactorily proved that any evasion of the duties has led to a more than corresponding augmentation of the cost laid down in England.

We shall on a future occasion return to this subject, one of prominent interest, and in the proper understanding of which the best interests of this port, moral and social, are most intimately connected.

Since the foregoing was written we learn that the duties and fines have been paid and the John Dugdale has proceeded on her voyage. If all Consignees of vessels will have the high moral courage to inform against the irregularities in other people’s shipments, there will soon be an end to all illicit trading.

div.head: Lady Mary Wood
div.p: The Lady Mary Wood sailed for Hongkong on Sunday last ; and currency has been given to a report that this will be her last voyage, as the Peninsular and Oriental Company propose discontinuing the Shanghae line, unless the mercantile community come forward with a standing subsidy in its aid.- It may indeed be the Steamer’s last voyage, as we believe she is required for some other of the Company’s branch lines ; but that this body contemplates abandoning its footing in Shanghae, whatever may be the response of the public to this novel demand, is a result of which we are more than sceptical. To do so would be at once to call competitors into the field, either English or American, who in the process of time might follow the expansive policy of the Company itself ; and far from contenting themselves with cast off coasting branches, seek a share of the profits attached to main lines and introduce a wholesome rivalry into the whole scheme of Oriental Steam Navigation. It may require cautious consideration before the Company extends its operations to any given locality ; but once established there we are much mistaken if it wilL see fit to abandon whatever prospects may have been entertained and whatever progress made, unless indeed in the improbable event of the enterprise turning out so worthless and hopeless, that no sane speculator would think of stepping into the vacated position.

But it is alleged that the Company are losing money by the extension of their line to Shanghae. If this really be the case, we regret it sincerely ; but can hardly admit that the question is thus dis-posed of. The experiment has scarcely existed for a year, and twelve months are an insufficient time to prove whether it be profitable or not. Nothing is more certain than that in the great facilities which modern science has afforded to communication and locomotion, their invariable tendency has been not only to develope but to create traffic; and it is from the new sources thus opened up that these costly enterprizes have derived in

a great measure their remuneration. Now we are more hopeful of the destinies of this port than to imagine for a moment we have yet fathomed the extent of its capabilities. Every year increases the magnitude of its stated trade, and every year is developing something new in that trade’s special features. Every year consequently is rendering it more fitted to support effectively a rudiment of Steam Navigation on the Chinese Coast and to remunerate better by the unforced expansion of commerce the pioneers of such an undertaking. Nor is it to be forgotten that in the particular operations of the Peninsular and Oriental Company the great value of the Shanghae branch is as a feeder to the main lines ; and in a comprehensive view of its pecuniary results should be estimated not only the limited earnings of the coasting Steamer but the returns from passengers and freight transferred by it to the Indian and English vessels, neither of which in many instances would have gone forward, but for the facilities afforded by a Steam communication throughout. If in the combination of these ultimate results with its. direct and immediate returns the Shanghae line is still a failure and likely to remain so,
we confess that we are much surprized at

At this juncture, then, the Company institutes a demand of one thousand dol-lars or so per month from the mercantile body here. It is true that no reason is given, and that the exaction is delicately regarded as a postage charge for the conveyance of letters ; but there can be no mistaking its unusual character. We presume the step has been taken in pursuance of instructions from head quarters; for the Company’s Agents in China could, we are satisfied, have given them much better advice as to what would he palatable to their supporters here, and beneficial to the best interests of their own body. We know not whether a similar demand will he made upon merchants at Hongkong, the other terminus of the line ; but at both places the matter must very soon be settled in one way or the other. We cannot suppose that either community will view with much complacency this attempt to tax them by a monthly subscription, though it may be difficult to decide whether they should seriously resent it or feel inclined rather to be amused at the originality of the idea. Certainly, of all the paltry expedients to which virtue in distress can be reduced we think the most undignified spectacle is that of a great commercial incorporation "sending round the hat,” as it has been proposed to do in the present case by the Peninsular and Oriental Company.

Let this undertaking, like every other, stand upon its own basis. If the line is not renumerating let the Company apply to Government for its assistance by a Post Office contract for the mails, as has been done in other instances all over the globe ; and if Government is obdurate to a well authenticated representation of this nature, let the concern be decently abandoned. But we can only regard the principle of a direct (and as far as lies in the power of a private body, an enforced) assessment-upon the public of any locality for the support of an undertaking in which they are but indirectly concerned as inherently vicious. What would be thought at home of the modesty of a railway company in difficulties which should seek to levy contributions for its own private advantage on every parish, through which its line might pass under a threat of stopping the conveyance of parcels or some other branch of traffic ? Or what of an insolvent trader who should send a circular to his creditors that unless they contributed so much a month to keep him afloat he would be under the unfortunate necessity of failing outright? We are certainly indebted to the Peninsular and Oriental Company for that more intimate connection with Europe which is the natural result of a direct Steam Navigation thence ; but we do not think that body has always been actuated by the most liberal sentiments or given effect to these in the most liberal way. It should occasion little surprize therefore if their present appeal to the mercantile body meets with a tardy and unwilling response ; and we await the issue of the proposal at all events with some curiosity. So far arc we, however, from regarding with apprehensions of its success the extension of Steam Navigation to this quar-ter, that we conceive in a very short time nothing less will meet the requirements of Shanghae than making it the terminus of the Bombay line, and Hongkong only the port of call. Drug will then be brought on without the necessity of transhipment with its attendant delay and risk, and we shall enjoy the advantage of a Steamer for each incoming and each outgoing mail. It might he well for the Peninsular and Oriental Company to anticipate this time, at least to facilitate its realization, certainly not to interpose such clumsy obstructions as that which we have noticed to the enlarged spirit of commercial enterprize and liberal dealing which should accompany the magnitude of their operations.

div.head: The Tea Trade
div.p: The article we give on the " Tea Trade,” is part of a series of articles which appeared in Hunt's Merchants Magazine, and was afterwards published in a pamphlet form at New York.

div.head: Pekin Reporter
div.p: SUMMARY and EXTRACTS. No. 118, Oct. 22nd and 23rdt 1850.

None of the ten Decrees given in this number treat on any subject worthy of notice; we therefore pass on to the memorials, of which there are two, addressed to His Majesty severally by Keying and by Lew Yunko, (Viceroy of Fuhkeèn and Che-keang. )

Keying entreats His Majesty to permit him to retire from his office promising when totally restored to health to “ lay his head in the mire at “ the Palace Gate, and crave to be again employed.” He thanks the Emperor for leave of absence which has been repeatedly granted him, and for the Gracious attention which has been vouchsafed to him in his ailments, and mourns that diligent exertion in the sphere of duty allotted to him, (which is the only means at his disposal of showing his ferment gratitude,) is totally out of his power. He speaks of the grievous ulcer that broke out in his neck, while on service at Tsing-keang in the spring of last year, and states that his medical adviser is of opinion that the constant drain of such a chronic sore, is sufficient to undermine his constitution and unfit him for all
exertion either of mind or body. He therefore
as a last resource, sends his memorial by the hand of his son, and beseeches that the Imperial Glance may be bestowed thereon.
Lew Yunko of Fuhkeen and Chekang writes as follows :—

Tseuenchow and Yungchun, (Taoutai at Amoy,) applied for leave last year to visit the Capital and obtain an audience, and afterwards falling ill at Peking, he left the service altogether. In consequence of which I received Your Majesty's instructions, directing me, as the post was one of extreme importance, to select an officer to fill the vacancy from among the whole number of Intendants in the Province, and to appoint Chang Hcyu to the office for the time being.”

“ The Intendant of Hinghwa, Tseuenchow, and Yngchun is I find placed over two primary departments and one secondary, comprising a tract of country situated in the southernmost extremity of Fuhkeen, and inhabited by a race of people who are obstinate and preverse, and indeed, proverbially difficult to govern. The town in which he holds his official residenoe, Amoy, is the most important sea port in the entire province, and the seat of its naval Command ; and being a great resort of all the mercantile marine of China, it presents no sinecure to the authorities who have to keep its thousands under subjection, and prevent the prevalence of crime. Ever since the establishment of commercial intercourse with western nations in the 23rd year of the late reign, forests of barbarian ships have also frequented its harbour ; England has placed a barbarian eye in the city and her vessels as well as those of America and Spain have constantly made it their resort. The civilised and the barbarian are thus thrown into constant collision, facilities for their falling out with each other naturally present themselves, and thus call for increased anxiety on the part of the authorities in charge. To secure good management under these circumstances and prevent all risk of failure, it is I conceive absolutely necessary that an officer of uncompromising dignity, and possessing a thorough know-, ledge of the barbarian language should be the person selected for this port Bearing this in mind assisted by the Commissioner of Justice and Finance, I have carefully weighed the capabilities of every individual Intendant of Circuit in the province, and really have not been able to discover cue at all suited to the situation, and therefore, fearing evil consequences, have not filled up the vacancy in that way ; Chang Heyu, the individual at present officiating is a Tsinsze of Szechuen, and was promoted from a district Magistracy in Kwangtung to the Prefectship of Nanning in Kwangse. When Seu Keyu Governor of Fuhkeen was Commissioner of Justice at Canton in the 23rd year of Taoukwang, he had constant opportunities of meeting this officer, then Magis-rtate of Pwanyu Ileen, and he found him to be not only a literary character but also a most clear headed able and experienced man, besides which he observed that he possessed an intimate knowledge of the Barbarian disposition. Taking into consideration the necessity of selecting an officer qualified for his post where, as in this irstance, the peculiar interests of a post of foreign trade, are concerned, and the fact that no other person besides Chang Heyu can be found possessing equal experience of the barbarians and their habits, I feel it my duty after consultation with the Commissioners of Justice and Finance to request Your Majesty in consideration of the importance of the office of Intendant of Circuit of these maritime districts, and the interests of the country comprised therein to permit Heyu to fill the vacancy.”

div.head: To the Editor of the North China Herald
div.p: Mr. Editor,—In the North-China Herald of the 14th December last, it is stated, that, if possible, the New Park will be completed in time for the next Spring Meeting of our Racing Club ; now that so speedy a termination to the exertions of the Committee who so kindly undertook the planning of the New Course, seems scarcely probable, will you allow me through the medium of your columns, to make a few suggestions respecting the much called for improvement of the present Park?

The ground intended for the formation of a new ride for the Community has not been taken possession of, so I presume that the actual settlement of it remains still a question of time, and the period of its completion, for either Riding or Racing purposes seems still more indefinite. I would therefore suggest, that the original plan which now appears to be both more expensive, and less easily accomplished, than was at first expected, be cast aside for the present, and our wants he supplied in the following manner.
For a good Racing and Riding ground suitable to our small Community, and
the horses used by them, I would pro-

pose that the Course be extended to the road leading from the village west of the Fives Court to the Soochow Creek, en-circling the Plantation at the west of the present Park, and forming the Course into a sort of oval, of which the Fives Court should be at one end and the proposed addition be at the other. The new portion either to be purchased entire, including all the land inside the Course, or merely buy or rent the land on which the new ride is formed, leaving the plantation &e., in the hands of the present owners. With such a course the coiners might be well rounded, and even Sydney and Arab horses have full swing in their gallops.

As a good country road is a great desideratum, I would suggest that one might be formed from the north west corner of the above proposed course, pass the north side of the village west of the Fives Court to the creek which bounds the Foreign ground over which let a new bridge be made (where the present wooden one stands) and from that take the first foot path to the south, widening it, and improving the small bridges until arrival at the "western road" and let the ride continue on that road to the red Joss house near the bubbling well ; and from it, return
along the north side of the creek that

runs east and west towards Shanghae, cross that creek about a quarter of a mile before arriving at the large stone Bridge beside the fir plantation, and continue east till arrived at the proposed new bridge over the creek which bounds the Foreign ground, and from thence proceed home by the course. e

From this circuit many good roads branch off, and it is only some small re pairs to bridges that are required to make capital roads from it, to the Pagoda by St. Catherine’s bridge to the French Mis-sionaries (Sze-kea-wei,} Yah-ke tun, Fat-wha, &e. Some compensation would be required for land lost by the widening of small paths, but the amount would be trifling.

If the above suggestions were carried into effect we would have a safe road of some five or six miles in extent, without a single paved village to pass through and only one large bridge to cross ; I can not estimate the expense of the improvements here suggested, but there is little doubt that all of them could be carried out at a much less expense than the pro. posed new Park, and I would even venture to say they would suit the wants of the Foreign Residents much better, for we would have both a good course and a safe country road quite completed in all probability before the new Park is even commenced.

I hope these remarks will lead to further suggestions for the improvement of country roads and that ere long we may be able to ride safely and comfortably to some distance from Shanghae.—I am Mr. Editor, your most obedient servant,

div.head: EXTRACT FROM “TEA AND TEA TRADE,’’ By Gideon Nye, Jr., of Canton. THE QUESTION OF CONSUMPTION IN THE UNITED STATES.
div.p: In reverting to the consideration of the question of the consumption in this country, we are always brought to the necessity of a more stable and uniform market here ;—the prevention of rapid and great fluctuation of prices, out of which spring the inducements to ship false and very inferior kinds of tea, from the introduction of which a distaste arises, and the use is checked.

The nature of this commerce, based as it is upon an article of prime necessity, which is the production of but one country, and that a distant one, and the extension of whose use follows so surely the diffusion of knowledge, and conducted, as well in second as in first hands, by a comparatively limited number of the most intelligent and respectable merchants whilst its importation is almost confined to this port*, should exempt it from the frequent and rapid fluctuations which coffee and other products of many, and of near, as well as distant countries, whose importation and sale is neither confined to a limited number of merchants, or to any one port, are subject.

In reviewing the trade for the last period of five years, we find a remarkable uniformity in its amount, as shown by the exports, from China hither, which, for convenience, we now repeat the gross sums of. Thus, there were shipped to "this country in—
Showing an average of about 14,323,000 pounds of green, and of about 4,9171,000 pounds of black ; and of both, 19,240,000 pounds per annum.—This presents a
uniformity such as no other article of importation does for a like period, and indicates a commerce free of the elements of fluctuation.

We find therefore, that the influences which have disturbed the course of prices here are external, or of an imaginary nature, and that the remedy lies in the adoption of a new system of sales, by which a regular and more gradual offering of the annual and inevitable accumulation of the importations in the spring may be provided for. As to the period of shipment from China, the laws of nature control the operations of the merchant ; for the incoming of the crop of tea at
the shipping ports is naturally in the autumn,
the monsoon soon after favours the vessel’s return hither; and the approaching season of humidity does not less powerfully than the winds tend to warn merchant against delay in China.

These natural and uncontrollable causes, then, indicate clearly the necessity of the suggested remedy. The considerations of its expediency have already been presented in the previous papers, in anticipation of the opening of the spring trade here ; and the subsequent course of the
